block.p: Makeshift Bombs Sow Rising Frustration in Iraq American commanders are expressing frustration at the increasing death toll in Iraq caused by makeshift explosives, which have killed 80 percent of the American forces who died in combat in the past three months, despite the billions of dollars being spent to combat the threat.
The number of unidentified corpses discovered in Baghdad soared more than 70 percent during May, according to the Iraqi Interior Ministry.

Sudan Aid Group in Upheaval Even with the seeming triumph of helping attain President Bush's new sanctions against Sudan, the Save Darfur Coalition, which helped bring the conflict to the world's attention, is in upheaval.
18 Killed in Clashes in Lebanon Lebanon's army moved closer to a Palestinian refugee camp where a group of militants has been hiding, seizing new ground in a fight that left 18 dead.
Video of Abducted Journalist For the first time since his abduction, a British reporter kidnapped in Gaza on March 12 was shown in a video released to an Islamic militant Web site.

Rice Tries to Ease Fears on Iran Secretary of State Condoleezza Rice sought to minimize any sense of division within the Bush administration over Iran after the head of the United Nations nuclear watchdog agency warned against what he called the ''new crazies'' pushing for military action against Tehran.

Toothpaste From ChinaIs Said to Contain Poison Consumers were advised to discard all toothpaste made in China after federal health officials said they found Chinese-made toothpaste containing a poison used in antifreeze in three locations -- Miami, the Port of Los Angeles and Puerto Rico.

New Rules on Student Loans The federal Education Department released proposed rules that would set new standards for universities and ban lenders' marketing practices that have resulted, in some cases, in loan company payoffs to university officials.

Close Bush Aide to Step Down Dan Bartlett, President Bush's longest-serving aide and one of his closest confidantes, said he was leaving the administration this summer, the latest departure in what has been a shrinking of President Bush's inner circle.

Kevorkian Leaves Prison Jack Kevorkian, the former pathologist who brought the debate over physician assisted suicide into the national spotlight a decade ago saying he had helped 130 terminally ill people in their deaths, stepped out of a Michigan prison having pledged not to assist anyone else.

Police Less Driven by Bias In making snap decisions about whether to shoot a potentially armed suspect, police officers are far less influenced by racial bias than students or community members forced to make the same decision, a large study has found.

Spitzer Pressing for Plan To Give Paid Family Leave Gov. Eliot Spitzer is pushing to win legislative backing for a plan that would give workers in New York State paid leave to care for newborn children or seriously ill family members.

Campaign Finance Limits The New York City Council is poised to introduce some of the most sweeping campaign finance restrictions in the country, aimed at limiting the influence of contractors, lobbyists, developers and others who do business with the city.
U.S. Economy on the Rise The economy appears to have shaken out of its slumber. In May, employers added nearly twice as many jobs as they did in April.

Meeting on Dow Jones Bid The decision to meet with the News Corporation could be a pivotal moment in the history of Dow Jones & Company and the Bancroft family, which has controlled it for more than a century. The meeting will take place Monday. C1

Sex Industry Declines The Internet was supposed to be a boon for the pornography industry, with wider distribution and social acceptance increasing sales. Now the business is in decline -- and the Internet is being held responsible.
Editorials: Budget tough talk; hot enough in here?; a cyberblockade in Estonia; Francis X. Clines on getting away to the country.
Columns: Bob Herbert and Timothy Egan.
Bridge B14 Crossword B14 Obituaries C10 TV Listings B15 Weather A14
